Description: Alnwick Castle served as the exterior of Hogwarts in the first two films, appearing in broomstick lesson and courtyard scenes.
Durham Cathedral cloisters and chapter house hosted many Hogwarts hallway and classroom interiors in the early movies.
Gloucester Cathedral's cloisters provided corridors for Hogwarts in multiple films, including the Chamber of Secrets warnings.
The Great Hall at Christ Church inspired Hogwarts' dining hall, and its grand staircase appears as the students' arrival stairs.
Oxford's Bodleian Library stood in for Hogwarts' infirmary and library reading rooms in the early films.
Platform 9¾ was filmed at King's Cross Station, with signage now commemorating the magical departure point to Hogwarts.
Leadenhall Market provided the exterior for the Leaky Cauldron entrance in *Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone*.

Placename: Warner Bros. Studios Leavesden, Hertfordshire, England
Description: Leavesden Studios hosted primary soundstages and sets for all eight films and now houses the official studio tour.
The Hogwarts Express crosses the curving Glenfinnan Viaduct in sweeping train shots seen across the series.
Sets for Hagrid's Hut and the rocky terrain near Buckbeak's execution were built in the glens around Glencoe.
Lacock Abbey's cloisters doubled as Hogwarts hallways, and its rooms were used for Snape's classroom and other interiors.
Hardwick Hall's exterior was used as the imposing Malfoy Manor in the final films.

Placename: Cliffs of Moher, County Clare, Ireland
Description: The dramatic Cliffs of Moher appear as the sea cave site where Dumbledore and Harry seek a Horcrux in *Half-Blood Prince*.
Freshwater West hosted the Shell Cottage set and the emotional burial of Dobby in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.
Goathland Station on the North Yorkshire Moors Railway portrayed Hogsmeade Station in the first film as students arrive by steam train.

Placename: Black Park Country Park, Buckinghamshire, England
Description: The dense woods of Black Park doubled for the Forbidden Forest across multiple movies, including night-time encounters and Buckbeak's flight.
The grand interior of Australia House on the Strand was used as the marble lobby of Gringotts Wizarding Bank in the early films.
The opening of *Half-Blood Prince* features Death Eaters destroying the Millennium Bridge in a dramatic sequence across the Thames.
New College's cloisters and courtyard hosted Hogwarts courtyard scenes, including Mad-Eye Moody turning Draco into a ferret.

Placename: Virginia Water Lake, Windsor Great Park, England
Description: Virginia Water was used as Black Lake shoreline in several films, including scenes with Buckbeak and Harry's Patronus practice.
Loch Shiel provided sweeping views of the Hogwarts lake in train shots and aerial flyovers alongside the viaduct.
The small island on Loch Eilt appeared as Dumbledore's final resting place and was used for reflective moments with the Hogwarts Express.
The limestone pavement of Malham Cove is where Harry and Hermione camp while on the run in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.
Puzzlewood in the Forest of Dean hosted the scene where Hermione's Silver Doe Patronus guides Harry to the Sword of Gryffindor.
Stoney Street in Borough Market housed the Leaky Cauldron entrance in *Prisoner of Azkaban*, where the Knight Bus drops Harry off.

Placename: St Pancras Renaissance Hotel, London, England
Description: The red-brick frontage of St Pancras Renaissance Hotel appears as the exterior of King's Cross Station when the Weasleys drop Harry at Platform 9¾.

Placename: London Zoo Reptile House, Regent's Park, England
Description: The Reptile House at London Zoo is where Harry speaks Parseltongue to a Burmese python in the first film.
Burnham Beeches' ancient woodland served as forest backdrops for Hagrid's hut approach and flying car crash scenes.
Whippendell Woods provided Forbidden Forest paths in *Sorcerer's Stone*, including the unicorn search with Firenze.

Placename: Glen Etive, Argyll and Bute, Scotland
Description: The desolate valley of Glen Etive features in *Deathly Hallows Part 1* as a camping spot for Harry, Ron, and Hermione after fleeing the wedding attack.
Swinley Forest stands in for the countryside where Snatchers chase the trio before their capture in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.

Placename: 12 Picket Post Close (4 Privet Drive), Bracknell, England
Description: This suburban house played the Dursleys' 4 Privet Drive exterior in the first film before the set was rebuilt at the studio lot.
Surbiton Station is where Dumbledore meets Harry in *Half-Blood Prince* as Harry reads about the Muggle Prime Minister in a café.
Ashridge Estate woodlands were used for *Goblet of Fire* Quidditch World Cup campsite scenes and as additional Forest of Dean backdrops.
Lacock's medieval High Street appears as Godric's Hollow and Budleigh Babberton, with cottages dressed for Harry's parents' home and Horace Slughorn's hideout.
De Vere House in Lavenham provided the façade of Harry's birthplace in Godric's Hollow during *Deathly Hallows Part 1* establishing shots.
Great Scotland Yard served as the street where Harry and Mr. Weasley enter the Ministry of Magic via a visitor entrance in *Order of the Phoenix*.
Lambeth Bridge is where the Knight Bus squeezes between two double-deckers in *Prisoner of Azkaban* as it races across London.

Placename: St Paul's Cathedral (Geometric Staircase), London, England
Description: The Geometric Staircase inside St Paul's Cathedral portrays the spiral steps to Professor Trelawney's Divination classroom in *Prisoner of Azkaban*.
Westminster Underground Station appears in *Order of the Phoenix* when Arthur Weasley escorts Harry to the Ministry for his hearing.
Loch Arkaig's island Eilean na Moine holds Dumbledore's tomb, seen as Voldemort steals the Elder Wand in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.
Steall Falls in Glen Nevis provides sweeping Highland scenery for Quidditch and Triwizard aerial shots in *Prisoner of Azkaban* and *Goblet of Fire*.
Remote Corrour Station on Rannoch Moor is where the Hogwarts Express stops unexpectedly in *Deathly Hallows Part 1* as Death Eaters search the train.
Loch Morar served as another Black Lake filming site for wide water vistas around Hogwarts across the early films.
Duke Humfrey's Library in the Bodleian served as Hogwarts' library reading room in the early films, where Hermione researches spells and secrets.

Placename: Claremont Square (12 Grimmauld Place), London, England
Description: The Georgian facades around Claremont Square portray the exterior of 12 Grimmauld Place, headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix in multiple films.
Harry, Ron, and Hermione apparate into Piccadilly Circus to escape the wedding attack at the start of *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.

Placename: Tottenham Court Road Cafe (Great Newport Street), London, England
Description: Just off Tottenham Court Road on Great Newport Street, the trio catch their breath before battling disguised Death Eaters in the cafe in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*.

Placename: Tower Bridge and City Hall Riverwalk, London, England
Description: The Thames riverwalk by Tower Bridge and City Hall appears as Death Eaters and the Order fly over London in *Half-Blood Prince* and *Order of the Phoenix*.
Battersea Power Station features in aerial flyover shots during the Order's broom escort of Harry across London in *Order of the Phoenix*.
Trafalgar Square opens *Half-Blood Prince* with Death Eaters swooping across central London before the bridge collapse montage.
The modern towers of Canary Wharf flash by during broomstick flyovers toward Grimmauld Place and the collapse of the Millennium Bridge in *Half-Blood Prince*.

Placename: Charing Cross Road (Leaky Cauldron Approach), London, England
Description: Charing Cross Road stands in for the street leading to the Leaky Cauldron in the first film, where Hagrid guides Harry into Diagon Alley.
The Mersey's Queensway Tunnel hosted the Knight Bus's high-speed dash in *Prisoner of Azkaban*, where the triple-decker squeezes through traffic.
Ivinghoe Beacon's windswept hilltop appears as one of the trio's camping spots in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*, where they scan the horizon for danger.
Sets for Little Whinging's Privet Drive and exterior chase scenes were built on Bovingdon Airfield during multiple films, providing controlled streetscapes.
Bourne Wood's tall pines hosted forest action for *Deathly Hallows*, including snatcher pursuits and atmospheric campsite shots.
The seaside town of Budleigh Salterton provided the exterior for the home where Dumbledore and Harry recruit Horace Slughorn in *Half-Blood Prince*.

Placename: Loch Etive, Argyll and Bute, Scotland
Description: Loch Etive's rugged shoreline features in *Deathly Hallows Part 2* as the trio leap onto the waterlogged banks after escaping Gringotts on the Ukrainian Ironbelly.
Coppett Hill in the Wye Valley was used for the Silver Doe patronus scene in *Deathly Hallows Part 1*, with Ron retrieving Gryffindor's sword from the icy pool.
The Old Schools Quadrangle at the Bodleian appears as part of the Hogwarts courtyard complex in the first films, framing students moving between classes.
Shots of the Jacobite Steam Train arriving near Mallaig Harbour stand in for the Hogwarts Express reaching the end of its route toward Hogsmeade.

Placename: Pickering Railway Station, North Yorkshire, England
Description: Pickering Station on the North Yorkshire Moors Railway provided period railway visuals alongside Goathland for early Hogwarts Express sequences.
Sweeping views in Glen Nevis Valley were captured for background plates of the Hogwarts grounds and Quidditch pitch in multiple films.

Placename: Eilean na Moine, Loch Eilt, Highlands, Scotland
Description: The small island of Eilean na Moine on Loch Eilt was used as Dumbledore's tomb, seen in Half-Blood Prince and Deathly Hallows Part 1.
Glenfinnan Station on the West Highland Line appears as the stop for the Hogwarts Express near Hogsmeade, paired with the nearby viaduct shots.

Placename: Blea Tarn, Lake District, Cumbria, England
Description: Blea Tarn provided one of the bleak camping spots for Harry and Hermione while hiding from Voldemort in Deathly Hallows Part 1.

Placename: Symonds Yat Rock, Forest of Dean, England
Description: Symonds Yat Rock lookout in the Forest of Dean appears when Harry and Hermione camp and look out over the valley in Deathly Hallows Part 1.

Placename: Frithsden Beeches, Ashridge Estate, Hertfordshire, England
Description: The open clearings at Frithsden Beeches were used for the Portkey landing to the Quidditch World Cup in Goblet of Fire.
Torren Lochan near Glencoe hosted the set for Hagrid's hut and the surrounding pumpkin patch area in Prisoner of Azkaban.
Savernake Forest provided woodland backdrops for Forbidden Forest stand-ins and camping plates during production.

Placename: Lochan na h-Achlaise, Rannoch Moor, Scotland
Description: Lochan na h-Achlaise on Rannoch Moor supplied sweeping moorland plates seen around the Hogwarts Express and in Deathly Hallows.

Placename: Harrow School (Fourth Form Room), London, England
Description: The Fourth Form Room at Harrow School doubled as Professor Flitwick's Charms classroom in the first film.

Placename: Black Rock Gorge, Ross and Cromarty, Scotland
Description: Black Rock Gorge near Evanton featured during the dragon chase sequence with the Hungarian Horntail in Goblet of Fire.
